author: m.kalinin
content:
More details on that. Client developers should fix me if I am wrong or missing anything
Complexity that we currently have: 
* Pull blocks and deposit data from EL client via JSON-RPC
* Keep the follow distance and cache the above data within the period
Can be replaced with:
* Have a logic that invalidates `Validator(pubkey, index)` cache entries on re-org -- potentially can be implemented in a couple of different ways

We should think a bit more on what alternatives we do have but as for now it looks like a reasonable trade off

author: sky.cactus
content: The other option would be to track system deposits until finality, then apply them.

author: m.kalinin
content: we would have to queue them in some layer and take non-finality into account

author: sky.cactus
content: The CLs could queue them independently, then come to consensus on them along with finality (or the first block after finality or something).

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, we don't actually have to specify the mechanism for tracking them up until finality is reached.

author: sky.cactus
content: A client *could* choose to not track them at all and then when finality is achieved they could walk the chain backward.

author: sky.cactus
content: Potential problem with this: If the chain isn't finalizing, no new validators can join.

author: sky.cactus
content: The chain cannot receive new validators until *after* enough validators leak out and the chain starts finalizing again.

author: m.kalinin
content:
We may actually have a queue of deposits in the beacon state. Considering that deposit entry is more or less of the same data complexity as the validator entry, this may work, except for the case when deposit tops up the balance but not creating the new record. Though, I think topping up is much less frequent

The problem of this scheme is requirement of seeking for *finalized* deposit index to drain the queue
